text: I think sometimes as Christians we read the Bible and read about God doing these miraculous works, and we think, wow, wouldn’t it have been cool to live then, maybe in the Old Testament where God was manifesting Himself in powerful, miraculous ways, or in the Book of Acts with lots of miracles going on. But God chose you to live now. Believe me, the people then would have coveted to live this close to Christ’s return, so never covet somebody else’s time in history because you’ve been blessed.
Pastor Chuck Smith, who many of us respect, said, 'The most important thing a born-again Christian can do is pray.'
Spurgeon said, 'I would rather teach one man to pray than ten men to preach.'
John Bunyan, the author of Pilgrim's Progress, said, 'You can do more than pray after you have prayed, but until we pray, we can't do more than pray.'

We need to hear them being shouted from Afghanistan right now. There are Americans who need to get out, people who’ve helped us over the last 20 years who we’ve made commitments to. You need to hear a shout from the other side of the planet saying, 'Pray for us.'
There are people who are hurting in Haiti. You need to hear this cry coming up for prayer.
There are Christians who are being persecuted around the world. There are people in Cuba who are believers being shut down by their government. You need to hear this cry for prayer.
You also need to hear it from the souls of your children who are in bondage to sin. Maybe it’s not coming out of their lips, but their hearts are crying for prayer.

I loved how John Courson would talk to non-Christians like they were already Christians. He’d be in the gym locker room, hear someone use the name of the Lord in vain, and say, 'Oh, you know Him too? Isn’t He wonderful?'

John Courson was heading to a retreat for his church youth group and stopped at a gas station. He said to the young attendant, a total stranger, 'Hey, I’m going up to a retreat right now, and I could really use some prayer. Would you just pray for me?'

After John Courson asked that gas station kid to pray for him, guess who was in church the next Sunday when John was preaching? Guess who gave his life to Christ within about two weeks? God works through prayer in ways we have yet to discover.

Last week I preached about authority, specifically government authority from Hebrews, because church leaders were telling people they needed to submit and obey. Somehow, repeated numbers of people got convinced I was teaching that Christians need to get the vaccination. I've checked my feelings, and I honestly don’t know where anybody could’ve gotten that, but the fact that so many did tells me it’s my fault, my failure.
Remember when Jesus went up on the Mount of Transfiguration? He comes down, and there’s a man who’s brought his son, who was demon-possessed, to His disciples.

I was thinking, and I often think of the parable of the Prodigal Son, which, by the way, Jesus never called it that. That's what we call it. There's great truths in there, and it really is the story of the self-righteous older brother as well.

You remember the story of the prodigal son, how he plans to say to his father, 'Father, I've sinned against heaven and in your sight. I'm not worthy to be called your son; hire me as one of your hired servants.' But the father interrupts him, falls on him with love, and says, 'You're not going to work for me; you're my boy. You were dead, but you're alive; you were lost, but now you're found.'
When I go to a restaurant and they wait on me, they're serving me. When I wait on the Lord, I'm serving Him. To wait on the Lord means to hope in God, to trust God's promises actively.

When the Amalekites come out to fight against the children of Israel, there needs to be a real battle. Joshua is sent down to fight the enemy in the valley, but Moses goes up on the mountain to pray and intercede, with Aaron helping hold up his hands. The battle has to be fought in the valley, but listen to me, it’s decided up on the hill of intercession.

Someone once said, actually my Bible professor at Biola, Dr. Mitchell, wrote a book called 'Let’s Pray.' In that book, he said what the church needs is to realize that it began in prayer. Remember, there in Acts, they were praying for 10 days waiting for the Spirit of God to come upon them, and when the Spirit came, everything changed.

In the Old Testament, King Asa of Judah faced a million-man Ethiopian army early in his reign. Overwhelmed, he cried out, 'Lord, we can't stand against them, you're gonna have to help!' God moved, gave him victory, and established his kingdom.

Years later, King Asa faced an attack from King Baasha of Israel during a civil war between the two kingdoms. Instead of talking to the Lord, Asa made an alliance with a foreign king, Ben-Haddad, saying, 'Hey, we've got a deal, attack him so he'll stop preparing to attack me.'

One time when Paul is standing before the high priest and some of the leaders who are questioning him, he says, 'I have kept a good conscience from my youth.' And the high priest ordered him to be slapped in the face, like that’s a lie. None of us can say that, but Paul was committed to having a clean and clear conscience.
It's kind of like I'm putting this problem in God's in-basket. He did say, 'Cast your cares upon me,' so I'm saying, 'Houston, Heaven, you've got a problem.' I'm turning this over to the Lord.

Remember when Jesus came down from the Mount of Transfiguration, a man had a demon-possessed son who would often throw him into the fire or water to drown him. The man brought him to Jesus’s disciples, but they couldn’t cast out the demon. The man said to Jesus, 'I brought him to your disciples, but they couldn’t help me.'
Matt suggests to you there are times like that, many times like that, because all the king’s horses and all the king’s men can’t put your boy back together again. You need the King Himself.
What did Jesus say after the man said that? He said, 'Bring him to me.' Folks, that’s what prayer is—bring him to me.

I think of the story of the Prodigal Son. It’s really not just about the prodigal; in context, it’s about the self-righteous older brother. But there’s great hope for parents whose children are out in the world, as the father, a picture of God, is so gracious, even giving the son his inheritance early, knowing he’ll waste it on riotous living.

The father sees him a long way off, runs to him. The boy starts his prepared speech, gets about half of it out, and the father cuts him off saying, 'I don’t need to hear your speech, you’re not applying for a job with me, you’re my son. You were dead and you’re alive, you were lost and you’re found, time to party, kill the fatted calf!'
Jesus is the Good Shepherd who will leave the hundred sheep and go find the one who is wandering and bring him home.

My daughter Chrissy backslid, went into the world. My wife became suicidal over it, and though we tried everything—even money—to bring her back to the Lord and our family, things just got worse. After two and a half years, I knew she was gonna die, my marriage was falling apart, and my wife was ready to leave the state.

At our church, we had a prayer meeting that more people attended than Sunday services. A thousand people would come out on a Tuesday night to pray. It was incredible to see that kind of commitment to seeking the Lord together.

During one of those Tuesday night prayer meetings, someone sent a note up to me on stage saying they felt a burden to pray for my daughter Chrissy right then. I didn’t even want to do it—I didn’t want the attention on me and my family, though folks knew what was happening—but I felt the Lord say, ‘Do it,’ so I asked the congregation to pray.

I remember coming back some years ago from Lancaster, not too familiar with the area. My mom had moved up there in the final stages of her cancer, and I drove up alone to spend time with her. I didn’t have a cellphone or GPS back then, just my laptop with some software and a little USB device on the dash acting as my guide, feeling pretty cool until it’d say ‘off route’ when I made a mistake.

I remember putting in the fastest way home on my GPS, thinking, 'Alright, this is why technology pays off, I’m gonna save some time.' But it took me through the Angeles Crest mountains, where I’m sure serial murderers live and die. I almost barfed twice, it took three hours, and I had to keep stopping—it was horrible.

I remember telling some friends the other night with Becky that when we bought my middle son his first two-wheel bicycle, he was so excited. But after falling a few times on the front lawn, he got frustrated, got up off the ground, walked into the house, and said, 'Why did you buy me a bike that always falls down?' It’s gotta be somebody else’s fault.
Mrs. Job, I don’t know what to call her, but I give her a pass since she lost her children. Yet, she tells Job, ‘You’re still trusting God after all this? Curse God and die.’

Jesus asks Peter, ‘Who do you say that I am?’ And Simon gets it right, saying, ‘Thou art the Christ, the Son of the Living God.’ Jesus responds, ‘Blessed are you, Simon, son of Jonas, flesh and blood has not revealed this to you, but my Father who is in heaven.’
Do you ever notice God asks questions in the Bible? You go, 'Well, God, I think you kinda know. There's the word of my mouth, you know it already.'
You know what God learns every day? The same thing my son learned every day in sixth grade. I'm asking on the way home, 'What’d you learn?' and he says, 'Nothing. Favorite subject? Lunch and recess.'

Becky and I made some decisions before we got married about never leaving one another in anger. But just two weeks after we got married, I got mad, grabbed my keys, and said, 'I'm out of here.' I got in my car, didn’t know where I was going, just wanted to show her who’s boss in this family.

I remember at 15, I’d worked all day at the gas station, and my mom says, ‘You need to take out the trash, clean your room, and then go clean the pool.’ I thought, are you kidding me? I’m exhausted, Lord, they’re so unfair!
I used to say I got saved because of drugs. I got drugged to church every Sunday, drugged to Sunday school every Sunday. I didn’t have an understanding of who God was or who Jesus was.

I went to a retreat at a church in Virginia. I wasn’t looking for God at all; I just didn’t think you had to find Him—He’s everywhere, right? But He was looking for me, even though I was very rebellious.
Jesus says to Nicodemus, ‘Hey, you have to be born again.’ Nicodemus says, ‘I don’t know what that means. Can I get back inside my mother’s womb?’ It’s like, okay, TMI there!

A pastor challenged his congregation with a 21-day no-complaint challenge. He gave them a purple plastic bracelet to wear as a reminder not to complain. If you mess up, you gotta switch it to the other wrist and start over, aiming to go 21 days without grumbling.

It's interesting, this fire from the Lord first starts to burn at the outskirts of the camp. Remember, the Lord is at the center of the camp, and the outskirts are those physically farthest from His presence.

So Moses says to the Lord, 'Why have you been so hard on your servant? Why have I not found favor in your sight that you’ve laid the burden of all these people on me?' It sure sounds to me like Moses is complaining, doesn’t it?
Have you ever heard a husband and wife talk about one of their sons or daughters doing something wrong, and they say, 'Your son!' It’s like, 'Did I adopt him? I think you were part of that!'
It’s like Moses is saying, 'These are not my people. These are your people, God. You conceived them; I was just out in the desert minding my father-in-law’s sheep when you showed up!'

Jonah's very upset about his little gourd plant dying. The sun beats down on it, and he says, 'Just kill me.' God says, 'Do you have good reason to be angry?' and Jonah replies, 'Yes, I do now that you mention it.'

Elijah wanted to die. The nation had just gone through an apparent revival, repentance, and God showed up in an amazing way. But then there's Jezebel, and even after God showed up in power, Elijah's worried because she said she's going to kill him.

Peter in the garden takes out the sword. Soldiers are coming in with Judas to get Jesus, and Peter says, 'Shall we strike with the sword?' Jesus doesn’t say anything, so Peter doesn’t wait for an answer and just starts cutting too soon.

Peter was ready to die for Christ, saying, 'I may die for you, but I won’t deny you.' But within just a short time, he changes his tune completely in front of a little slave girl. He’ll stand against soldiers, but not against her.

Elijah reminds me of Peter. He’ll stand in front of the whole nation, preach God, and God shows up in power. But then some godless woman says, 'You’re dead,' and he runs out under a juniper tree, saying, 'Take me home, God,' so discouraged.

You find again and again in Scripture people that are kinda overwhelmed by God's decision to bless them and to use them, and they wind up saying these words, 'Who am I? Who am I that the God of all the earth would choose me?' I'm nobody, and yet God has His eye on me.

You know, people like to talk about their heritage. They go and get their DNA done, and sometimes they're pretty proud of it. Hey, let me tell you, I got 23andMe, and now I can tell you my roots, though when I looked at mine, it’s like 23 and whoopty dee.
You know what happens before all-out war happens? That home country recalls its ambassadors. That's called the rapture, by the way, and we're going to be called home.
In the King James, it says you are a peculiar people. Some think that means we're weird—and some of us are—but someone once said, 'Well, we are odd and we are flawed, but we're precious to God.'

Think about common things like a book, a desk, a pipe, or some sheet music. They're not so exciting until you discover the book belonged to Abraham Lincoln, the desk is where Churchill wrote his memoirs, the pipe belonged to C.S. Lewis, and the sheet music was handwritten by Beethoven. Suddenly, these ordinary things become extremely valuable.

When God wants to reveal what His people—His unfaithful, stiff-necked people—are in His estimation, He has them represented on the high priest's ephod, on his breastplate, with 12 stones. Each one is different, each one a gemstone. It's not like they're mostly gemstones and then there's, you know, a dirt clod or something.

A man on the West Coast went on vacation to the East Coast years ago, where there were two famous radio preachers. He visited both churches and later told his friend, 'Pastor A is a wonderful preacher, but Pastor B has a wonderful Savior.'

I saw a guy I met at the Orient, didn’t know him well, and I said, 'Hey, what’s new?' He replied with the 13th letter of the Greek alphabet. I thought, 'Huh, he’s already studying, trying to bring the curve up,' and I just said, 'Well, it’s all Greek to me.'
You couldn't choose your birth parents, but you can choose to be born into God's family. Jesus said to his disciples, 'You did not choose me, but I chose you.'

I’ll never forget, I went to get a cup of coffee at my son’s house. I grabbed a guy cup—y’know, I don’t like girl cups, just not me—and my grandson said, ‘Oh, you don’t want that cup.’ I asked why, and he said, ‘Cause there’s one with a picture of me on it, you want that one, right?’

I came to my wife and said, 'Hey, you're incredibly beautiful,' and she’d say, 'No, I'm not, I'm getting older now.' I said, 'You're an amazing cook,' and she goes, 'No, the food didn't turn out the way I expected at all.' I told her, 'I love the way you decorate our house,' and she reminds me of that one time I tried to decorate right after we got married, and it was a big mistake.

Right after we got married, I decided I was going to own this one little piece of the house. I told her, 'You've decorated the rest, that's fine, but this is mine.' She asked, 'Well, what's your style?' and I just went, 'Style?'

Can you imagine yanking somebody off the Titanic who was in the water, and you brought them on board, and they go, 'Oh, I just feel like I'm still out there'? Well, you'll get over that. I think I'm going down? Well, I don't know why, you need a shrink, but you're safe.
We've just started a new thing. This is a certificate that our media department, my son actually designed, and it's beautiful. I've signed it to recognize this day so you can remind him.
This is his first Bible, and so we hope you'll enjoy that. God bless you guys.

Asaph wrote in Psalm 78 about the sons of Ephraim, who were archers equipped with bows—special forces, you might say. Yet they turned back in the day of battle, they didn’t keep God’s covenant, and refused to walk in His law. They forgot His deeds and miracles, and because of that, they became defeated and disobedient.

She was once asked what heaven would be like, and she said, 'I can tell you this, if I could go back and have vision my whole life, I would never do it.' When asked why, she said, 'Because for me, the first person I’ll ever see is Jesus when my eyes are opened, and I cannot wait.'

There are some, maybe in this room, who are dual citizens. My wife was born in Brazil but she’s an American born to American parents, so for a time she had dual citizenship. Jim Carrey is American and Canadian, Tom Hanks is American and also a citizen of Greece, Sandra Bullock is American and has German citizenship.

If you’re a Christian, I don’t care what nation you’re from, you have dual citizenship. You’re not gonna need a visa to go to heaven—why? Because you’re just going home, you’re going where you belong.
Nobody becomes a naturalized citizen of heaven. You have to be a supernaturalized citizen—you have to be born into His kingdom.

The Bible says we are ambassadors for Christ. Have you ever thought about that? An ambassador is somebody who represents one nation to another nation, going to that other nation to represent the king or leader of their nation.

I said, my mom and dad aren't here, I could tell the neighborhood to get off my lawn, but now this is a bit more real. My mom and dad are here, I don't own this house, and I don't have a dollar, so I can't really give you an answer right now. She got frustrated and walked off.

George Robinson wrote a song that some of us grew up singing, and some of us can maybe really relate to. He said, heaven above is softer blue, earth around a sweeter green, something lives in every hue, every color that Christless eyes have never seen.

Big Bill Sprouse, a country western singer, described his conversion like this: 'It was like I was inside a giant blob of Jello, and the day I got saved was like I broke out and took my first breath.' I thought, what a good picture of conversion—you don’t even know what it’s like until it’s happening.
This verse, Colossians 1:13, says God translated us from one kingdom to another. It’s like Star Trek—'Beam me up, Scotty!' I was there in darkness, and I got translated into God’s kingdom.

I'm not proud of it, but I'm not ashamed to be honest and tell you I was a rebel, pot-smoking thief before I got saved. Some of you might say, 'I don't like who you were, and because of that, I don't trust who you are.' I don't blame you, because I don't like who I was, and I don't trust who I am either, but I'm not asking you to trust me—I'm asking you to trust Him, and I'm here to tell you what He can do with you because He's done it with me.

Years ago, there were two famous Christian pastors on the East Coast. A friend from the West Coast went on vacation and visited both their churches. When he came back, I asked him to compare them, and he said, 'Pastor A is a wonderful preacher, but Pastor B has a wonderful Savior.'

Maybe you think, wow, it'd be so cool to have lived in the Old Testament, to have seen manna come down from the sky, or to gather it every day in the wilderness, or to see the pillar of cloud leading them. I mean, the water out of the rock, and quail—where's the beef? God just providing and manifesting Himself through miracles and the ten plagues; I would have loved to have lived back then.

What if I went up to my wife Becky and said, 'You are incredibly beautiful,' and she says, 'No, I'm not, I'm getting old, my hair...' I say, 'You really are beautiful,' and she still denies it. I tell her, 'You're an amazing cook, we don’t eat at home like we used to, but man, I love it every time we do,' and she says, 'No, my mom was better, I struggle at that.'

Peter says, 'Wow, it's awesome, we should just stay here and have three tents, one for each of them.' And God says, 'Pipe down, Peter, this is my Son, listen to Him.' Peter never forgot that day; he writes about it in II Peter, saying we were eyewitnesses, we heard the divine utterance.

I have a friend who comes to our church, and years ago he needed dialysis due to kidney issues. He was getting weaker, had to leave his job, and was mostly bedridden, hoping for a transplant. He told me, 'Bob, I went to see my kidney doctor, and the doc asked how I was doing. I said good, but he said, no you're not. I insisted I had a good week, but he kept saying, no you haven't.'

He said, 'Why do you keep saying that?' I told him, 'Because you don't know what it feels like to be healthy. You're so used to being sick, you've accepted and acclimated to this life, but your life's gonna change when that transplant happens.'
There was this guy racked in pain on his deathbed, and a friend came up and quietly said, 'How are you doing?' He replied, 'Almost better. Give me a few minutes, and I’ll be much better.'

Years ago, I prayed for a man who was going blind. After we finished praying, he looked at the group of men laying hands on him and said, 'You know, five years from now, you might see me bumping into trees, but I’ll know one thing—even if I can’t see a thing, I’m healed.' I thought, yeah, that’s just utter deception, buddy; that’s not true.

Job had taken a hit—lost his children, wealth, reputation, servants, and now he’s got these boils breaking out all over. He’s scraping them, a sad sight, and the devil said, ‘Skin for skin, if I touch his body, he’ll curse you, God, living in this misery.’ But Job didn’t curse God, even when his health was taken away.

The Companion Bible points out something interesting about these boils. They didn’t just grab soot from any old kiln; the Hebrew definite article shows it’s from an altar, one used for human sacrifice to avert plagues. This soot might be tied to worship of the god Set, who supposedly had authority over such things.

Years ago, there was a strike in Las Vegas, and all the casinos closed down because they didn’t have enough workers. It was completely dark, and I make the analogy between these altars and idols shutting down in Egypt, unable to continue false worship, and Las Vegas being shut down, showing the place of sin as the dark place it really is.

It's interesting to me, there were some in Pharaoh's court who must have been overhearing what was being said. While Pharaoh isn't believing, they're going, 'I think we'd better get the dogs and honey, get the cows in the house. I don't know if it's gonna happen, but everything else he said is happening.'

You know, when I was growing up, divorce was almost unheard of among unbelievers. People didn't live together outside of marriage and brag about it. The world called that 'shacking up,' and no one was proud of that.

When I finished the police academy, I remember getting very excited about going out and doing the job. You spend time in training, learning how to handle different things, but it’s all academic until you get out there and actually perform the job. It’s kind of exciting to be called into something.

Listen to this true story. She owns a string of hotels, the Empire State Building, she's a billionaire, yet in September 1989, Leona Mindy Rosenthal Helmsley was convicted of 33 counts of tax evasion and spent time in prison. According to Time Magazine, she emerged as a penny-pinching tyrant who tried to stiff just about everybody, no amount of money was too small to fight over.

When I was young, I remember hearing about the gift of singleness, and that was a scary thing. I mean, you read the gifts in the Bible—prophesying, speaking in tongues, miracles, preaching—and singleness isn’t even in the list in 1 Corinthians 12 or Ephesians 4. But Paul brings it up in 1 Corinthians 7, saying he’s called to it and recommends it, and I’m thinking, what if we don’t want to be single?

As a young person, I remember thinking about singleness like it was a disease. We’d look at each other like, ‘What if we got it?’ It’s like, nobody wants to go out with you, man, it’s terrible, nobody’s ever gonna like me, and I’m just gonna be single forever.

I used to tell this at weddings, but my wife told me to stop. I talked about the three rings of marriage: there's the engagement ring, the wedding ring, and the suffer ring. She said, 'That's terrible, don't say that!'
When I got married, I was looking for the ideal, but what I found was an ordeal, and now I'm looking for a new deal.

Think about Abraham, he was wealthy. He didn't just have some servants; he had like his own special forces. Remember when Lot got kidnapped in the battle down in Sodom, and Abraham leads the trained men out of his home like they're all special ops guys, they whoop them and get Lot and the family back.

I heard about this guy who went down to the beach and saw a man standing on the shore with his dog. The man threw a stick out into the ocean, and the dog ran on top of the water, picked up the stick, and came running back on top of the water. The guy watching was amazed, but when he asked about it, the man just said, 'Yeah, your dog doesn’t know how to swim, does he?'

I have a friend who God has chosen to bless with a worldwide ministry. I've known him for a long time, and I'm so excited for him because God's doing stuff we prayed about years ago. A couple years ago, I told him how blown away I am by what God's doing in his life, and he looked at me and said, 'You're a true friend,' because not all his friends are happy for him.

I heard a story of a man who decided he’d lived in his house for quite a while and thought it was the right market to sell. He’d been thinking about moving for a long time, so he called a realtor and said, 'I don’t know, I’ve lived here a long time, I don’t know what to do.' The realtor said, 'Okay, I can help you, let’s write up everything commendable about your house and neighborhood.'

I remember when I was a police officer, I had a friend who was single but a Christian. God had blessed this guy with business sense. He was a cop, but he had a side business with vending machines, raking in the dough, buying houses right here in Orange County back in the day.
Can you imagine if the stars only came out one night a year? I think everybody would stay up all night to see them, but because they’re far more available to us, we ignore them.

Think of Manna in the Old Testament. It’s a miracle—they’re starving in the wilderness, and God brings this miraculous bread. It wasn’t just a loaf; they could grind it up, make different items out of it, even joke about manicotti, and it satisfied them for a while.

A few years ago, we had to get out because the fire was coming up over the hill. We met down at the 7-Eleven, they were clearing the streets, and I remember standing there with my wife and sons, saying, 'Everything that matters to me is right here. I have the Lord and my family; I care, but I don’t care that much.'

After the church service, a little boy came up to me and said, 'You know, when I grow up, I'm gonna give you some money.' I said, 'That's very nice, but why do you say that?' He replied, 'Well, because my dad says you're one of the poorest preachers we've ever had.'

One pastor had installed blow dryers in the bathrooms, but after two weeks, he had them taken out. Someone in the church asked, 'Why did you take those out? They work just fine.' He said, 'Well, one day I went in there, and there was a sign on it that said, for a sample of this week's sermon, push the button—hot air.'

I'm a good little home project—go through all the epistles of Paul and see how many people are on his prayer list. He had a huge prayer list. He doesn't just say, 'Oh, I prayed for you once,' but 'I'm praying for you night and day, constantly.'

Here’s Paul, on death row in a dark, dank dungeon—not house arrest like in Acts—but he’s still praising God and praying. Why? Because he learned his lesson in Acts 16 in Philippi, in jail, to praise God wherever he is.

I'll never forget this guy at the service station where I worked when I was young. Whenever he got hurt, he'd get so angry, take off his glasses, and throw them across the room, smashing them. I don’t know how many pairs of glasses he went through, but that was just his style.
You can't always be sure of someone else's faith. Remember, Judas looked like the real deal. When Jesus said one of you will betray me, they didn’t all point at Judas; they said, 'Is it I?'

Jesus marveled at this man and said, 'I have not seen such great faith in all of Israel.' Here's a Gentile who has great faith, and wouldn't you think that might have been encouraging to the guy, besides getting the boy healed?

The Syrophoenician woman, another Gentile, persists and persists, saying, 'Please cast the demon out of my daughter.' Jesus seems to ignore her, but she keeps on, and even when He says, 'It's not right to take the bread from the children's table and give it to the dogs,' she responds, 'You're right, but even the dogs get the crumbs.' Then Jesus turns and says, 'Woman, great is your faith, be it done unto you according to your faith.'
I wonder how many times a saint looks at us and says, 'You are the weakest link, goodbye.' It's our privilege to be part of what God has been doing.

I took the Four Spiritual Laws and went to my mom’s room. I said, 'Mom, can we pray?' She said, 'Sure, what do you want to pray about?' I told her, 'I’d like you to pray this prayer on the back of the booklet.' She said, 'Well, that’s the sinner’s prayer to become a Christian.' I said, 'Uh-huh,' and she replied, 'I already am a Christian.' I thought, 'Mom, I know you think you are,' but that moment changed my life.
Robin Williams gave a definition of politics. He said it's two words in Latin: 'poly,' which means many, and 'ticks,' which means blood-sucking creatures. So, that's what politics is to him.

Becky and I are currently watching my sister's dog. We haven't had a dog for a while, so we're glad to be doing that, and we're glad it's temporary at the same time. This little dog named Summer loves to have her tummy rubbed, just like every dog you've ever been around.

They might say, 'The thief on the cross never went to church, but he got into heaven.' That's true, there wasn't a church for another 43 days if I read my Bible correctly, but that's not a good excuse for why you should honor the Lord when He says don't forsake the assembling of yourselves together.

Years ago, someone said to me, 'I know God hates divorce, me too, but God understands my situation and He would not want His daughter to be unhappy, so I'm not going to honor that, I'm not going to stay with my husband.'

Years before, someone said to me, 'I know he's not a Christian, but I prayed about it and I feel led to date him. I have a total peace about it. After all, how can it be so wrong when it feels so right?'

In Philippi, Paul and Silas were beaten and thrown into jail. Before I was chief of police in Placentia, I was chief in Marysville, a small town up the coast. Not long after I became chief, I got a call at night from one of my officers. They had arrested a drunk driver, had him out on the street, and were wondering if they should take him in.

County sheriffs usually have a lot of political weight compared to little city police officers, especially new ones. He asked, 'Is he drunk?' I said, 'Yes.' He said, 'Book him.' Sharon, a godly woman, listened as I worried about blowing my whole career. She said, 'Honey, the Bible says in Proverbs 3:5-6, trust in the Lord with all your heart and lean not on your own understanding. In all your ways acknowledge Him, and He'll make your paths straight.'

Jacob has just met the Lord face to face, and he calls the place the face of God. He's lived through it, and now he realizes God wants him to get right with his brother who he offended twenty years before.

The next Sunday, Thomas came to church, got together with the disciples, and Jesus shows up. After Jesus confronts him, Thomas says, ‘My Lord and my God.’ Up to this point, Jacob has never called God his God, but Thomas makes that declaration after seeing and believing.

The wise man told him to meet at the beach, and when they went into the water, the young man thought he’d be baptized, but the older man held him under until he passed out, then dragged him to shore.

I had a friend in high school, a Christian, and we were in the same youth group. Her brother Joe, coming home late at night, fell asleep at the wheel in a solo car accident and tragically died. The family was weeping, it was a heavy moment. Then someone started the chorus, 'He is here, He is here, He is moving among us,' and we just started worshiping the Lord in the midst of this terrible tragedy. The presence of God came on this group of about 50 of us as we were worshiping that morning—I can’t explain it, but if you know what I’m talking about, you know what I’m talking about.

You know, these are little kids, and one kid was bragging, 'My dad, he's a lawyer, everybody knows my dad.' Another kid said, 'Oh, my dad, he's a bank president, in charge of all the money.' My grandson tells me every time he's around any water, 'Grandpa, can you baptize me?' I say, 'Sure, but not right now. We're just at a pool, your mom and dad aren't here, and we're not gonna do it just yet.'
I was down at Pirate’s Cove with my grandson, and he goes, 'You do baptisms right here?' I said, 'No, not just yet, but this is where we do them.'
I remember doing a baptism of a little girl many years ago; she was three. Now, that’s pretty young, and I’m not saying it’s typical.

I've told you before that when I went to Cuba, I had the privilege of leading a 16-year-old man named Richard to Christ. I left not knowing if I'd ever see him again, but we wrote letters back then—no internet—and I encouraged him and his friend to walk with the Lord. I gave him a Bible, and later he asked me to come back and baptize them, which I did, and his dad even wanted to meet me.

I went to this young man's home outside Havana, in a third-story tenement housing. His dad, Andre, a card-carrying communist and atheist, was very concerned about his son reading the Bible and wanting to be baptized, influenced by me, a Christian pastor from the States. The whole family—25 people—stood around watching us, not talking, just staring as we sat face-to-face with Richard translating.
He said something simple in Spanish I could understand: 'Mi casa es su casa.' Your house is my house. Then he joked, 'Mi esposa, my wife, is not your wife,' and I just smiled at him.
Long story short, he comes to Christ, and the whole family gave their life to the Lord that day. The entire family received Christ—it was amazing.
Honey is delicious, but if you eat too much of it, it will make you sick. Just like sexual sin, it’s pleasurable, but it will ultimately destroy you.

Years ago, Becky and I were looking to buy our first house. It was a nervous time back when houses were a hundred thousand dollars—imagine, you’d buy ten homes for that now! We couldn’t afford Orange County, so a friend, a fellow police officer, told us to come see these amazing new homes out by the Tyler Mall in Riverside, and man, they were gorgeous with beautiful bay windows and huge master bedrooms.

I remember looking at this model home, and man, it was perfect—lush grass, fully furnished, a no-brainer. Then my friend invited us to see his place in the same complex, and it was a mess—empty rooms, boxes of junk, nothing like the model. Many years ago, a man named George Wilson committed murder during a train robbery, killed a guard, and was sentenced to death by hanging. Though public sentiment was against capital punishment, President Jackson issued a presidential pardon, but Wilson refused to accept it. Chief Justice John Marshall said, 'A pardon is a parchment whose only value must be determined by the receiver of the pardon; it has no value apart from that.'

George Wilson has refused to accept the pardon. We cannot conceive why he would do so, but he has. Therefore, George Wilson must die, and on a day appointed by that court, he was taken from his cell and hanged to satisfy the requirements of the law.

God creates light, which is part of the electromagnetic force in the universe. There are four fundamental forces in physics—weak force, strong force, gravity, and electromagnetic force—and electromagnetic force is responsible for all light. God made light to teach us something about who He is, even though He Himself is invisible.

This morning, Becky said to me, 'What time is it?' I said, 'It's almost six,' and she asked, 'Do you want to get up?' I said, 'It's still dark.' But the light God has created, the time of a new morning, teaches us things. One of those is that the light comes to wake us up, to get us moving, showing there is hope in the fact that God is light.

National Geographic covered a wildfire in the Midwest that destroyed farmland. A photographer found a chicken, completely burned to a crisp, but underneath its wings, baby chicks came out alive. That hen had given her life for her babies.

I was in Sharpsburg one night, snuck into the edges of your camp, and saw you on picket duty, all alone in that broad moonlight. I raised my rifle, knew I could take you out and get away, but just before I shot, you started singing 'Savior, Like a Shepherd Lead Us,' and memories flooded my mind of my mom singing that to me as a boy.

He said, 'Sir, when you were done singing, I raised my rifle to take your life, but I couldn’t pull the trigger. So I put my rifle down and snuck away into the night. You never knew I was there, but your Shepherd was protecting you.'

My wife suffered for three years with tinnitus, a horrible ringing in the ears that never goes away. We prayed, went to the emergency room twice, had MRIs, and found no help—until a specialist from our church, who works at the Cleveland Clinic, offered to fly us out for a three-day evaluation. But just before we went, after women from our church prayed and fasted for her, Becky woke me up crying, saying, 'It’s gone.'

She said, 'The sound of my tinnitus is gone!' I said, 'You're kidding!' She says, 'Completely done,' and she was weeping, had to call her sister in the middle of the night to wake her up and celebrate because she was one of the people praying for it. That was years ago, and it's never come back.

Over in England, some stores play a frequency that only teenagers and younger can hear to keep kids from hanging out after school. It’s annoying to them, but adults don’t hear it. Do you remember when Naaman got healed of leprosy? It says he didn’t just get healed; he had the flesh of a little child. When God heals, He does a good job.

In the 1989 earthquake in Armenia, a father rushed to his son’s school, finding it flattened. Remembering his promise, ‘No matter what, I’ll always be there for you,’ he dug through the rubble, driven by his commitment, even as other grieving parents arrived.

A father dug through the debris of a collapsed school for 38 hours to find his son. Despite the fire chief, police, and others telling him to go home, saying it’s too late and dangerous, he kept asking, 'Will you help me now?' Finally, he heard his son’s voice, 'Dad, it’s me. He explained, 'Even as Jonah was in the belly of the great fish three days and three nights, so shall the Son of Man be in the heart of the earth three days and three nights.'

A missionary was in a foreign country, trying to share Jesus with his Buddhist neighbor. The neighbor said, 'I don’t see any difference between what you believe and what we believe; we all believe in a higher power. Can you tell me the difference?' That day, there was a big parade in town presenting a bone of Buddha as a relic to a local temple. The missionary said, 'I can tell you the difference between Christianity and Buddhism right now. If they ever found a bone of Jesus Christ, we wouldn’t celebrate; the whole Christian world would mourn because He came alive from the dead. That separates Christianity from every other religion whose founders are all dead.'

A Muslim who came to Christ was asked by his friend, 'Why did you become a Christian? It doesn’t make sense to us why you’d leave the Muslim faith.' He replied, 'Well, it’s kinda like this. If you were lost going down a road and came to a fork, and there were two men there—one dead and one alive—who would you ask for directions? Jesus Christ is alive.'

Years ago, I lived in Placentia, and our home had these beautiful trees. The city owned them and would come out every couple of years to trim them back. Wayne, our sound man, told me a story the other day about his son. They were building things together, his son in a diaper, nailing things into the house they built. Those nails are still in the walls somewhere, and it’s just beautiful stuff, this life we have.

Even the devil quotes the Bible to the author of the Bible to try to get Him to disobey. One dark night in a forest in Sicily, Italy, a robber held up a book peddler at gunpoint, ordering him to burn his books. Then she discovered her lips had extreme sensitivity her fingers no longer did, and she read the entire Bible through with her lips because she loved God's word so much.

William, a rough, worldly construction worker from Scotland, was handling dynamite on the job when it blew both his hands off and blinded him. In that dark time, someone shared the gospel, he got saved, and though disabled and unable to work, he heard about Marie reading the Bible with her lips. He tried it too, desperate to learn Braille and read Scripture, even though the explosion had damaged his lips as well.
