The attendant recognized the pastor, and while waiting in this long line, he said, 'Sorry, Pastor, I don’t know why everybody waits to the last second to go on a long trip.' The pastor replied, 'Same way in my business.'

I was talking to Becky when I went to see my friend Fred. Fred was my age, and there’s a distinct look a person has when they’ve died, but what amazed me is how much Fred looked like his father. I knew his father; he was my first boss at a gas station when I was 13, and I was there when his dad died.

Brasilia, an 80-year-old man, came out to welcome King David back after Absalom's rebellion. David said, 'Come live with me in Jerusalem, I'll provide for you,' but Brasilia replied, 'No, please let your servant return to my home, that I may die in my own city near the grave of my father and my mother.'

When I sat there with my friend, of course I wished he was alive, that I could pray over him, pray for his healing, or comfort him, but he was gone. All I could think was he’s with Carol who passed a couple years ago, he’s with Fred and Della, his mom and dad who I love, and I know they’ve been waiting for him up there. I know he’s with Jesus, and he loves Jesus, so I wouldn’t want him back—how selfish would that be? I was utterly encouraged because I knew he was with his family.

A few months ago, Becky and I were part of the funeral procession for Highway Patrol Sergeant Steve Lacan. There were hundreds of highway patrolmen and police officers, probably about a thousand, all in uniform at Harvest Church, and then this incredible processional to the cemetery like I’ve never seen. We were in my car toward the back of this long line of police cars, with the hearse surrounded by CHP motor units, lights on, cops everywhere, and at every intersection, officers stopping traffic, while people on the streets of Riverside stood watching, sensing something important was happening.

I thought how precious this moment is. Jacob never had this kind of honor given to him while he was alive, but now, after his death, all these Egyptian heads of state are honoring him because of his relationship to Joseph.

I’ll never forget when my mom was dying. I needed to move her from a couch to a bed, and I picked her up in my arms. I thought, I don’t know that I’ve ever carried my mother before, but this is a time for that.

My original family—me, one brother, three sisters—came together the night we knew Dad was dying. It was just us, the nuclear family, down at my parents’ mobile home in South County, watching the monitor as he slowly came to the end of his life. It was a special time; we hadn’t been together like that in many, many years, but his death brought us together.

My dad decided, 'I don’t want a funeral service. I want you guys to go out and have ribs, and I’m paying for it.' So we all went out, had ribs, and my brother Bill and I—eternity apart in worldviews, me a cop, him a defense attorney, him liberal, me not, him an atheist or agnostic, me not—were brought together at that rib joint, talking about childhood memories and weeping together, celebrating our father.

Growing up, there was a bottle in our medicine chest labeled 'Pretty Feet.' I thought it was kind of an oxymoron, you know, pretty feet, but it was some kind of dead skin remover, mostly used on elbows rather than feet.

I think of the two men who shared the gospel with me so many years ago. They had pretty feet—not that they took their shoes off—but they had pretty feet because they brought me information about how I can know my Savior, and it changed my life.

True story, when I was a police officer, I had this huge sergeant who didn’t like Christians. He let me know in many colorful ways, and I tried to avoid him as much as I could. After I left the department, I went back for a visit, and he says, 'Hey, Kopeny, I wanna talk to you,' and I thought, oh great, here comes something offensive again, but we sat down with coffee in the briefing room, and he surprised me.
One organization has this motto I like: every Christian is a missionary and every unsaved person is a mission field.

As we were driving out of the church parking lot in Rhode Island, I saw signs all over that said, 'You're now entering your mission field.' They were there to remind everyone, every Sunday or Wednesday night, as they left the church, that they’re stepping into their mission field.

I have a friend who had a sign above his front door that said, 'You're now entering your mission field.' Every time he and his wife walked out, they were reminded of their mission. Some of you with unsaved people at home might need one on both sides of the door!

We have a ministry down in Mexico, and we do it on purpose so anybody can take their weekend and say, 'I want to go down and minister or help those sharing the gospel there.' It’s close enough, even if you can’t go to Romania, Cuba, or India with me.

Years ago, a family, the Schafer's, had a little daughter named Brittany, maybe seven or eight. On one of our trips home from Ensenada, Mexico, an adult who’d just gone and was thrilled about God using them turned to Brittany, who came down every couple months with her family, and asked, 'So Brittany, when you grow up, do you want to become a missionary?' She said, 'No, I already am one.'

I've heard people as a Christian say my whole life about serving the Lord in some new capacity, whether it's full-time ministry as a pastor, evangelist, or missionary, 'If the Lord opens the doors, I'll go.' May I suggest, when I read the Great Commission, the doors were opened two thousand years ago.
Today is an extra special day for me. It's my dad's birthday, and I need your help embarrassing him. So, will you join me in singing happy birthday to him?

I heard a story years ago about some people that went to Wales to witness a revival that had broken out there. It’s famous, called the Welsh Revival. They had heard about it and got there to see it for themselves.

Do what Gypsy Smith years ago said to people who wanted to see Revival. He said, 'Draw a circle, go home, get in that circle, and when everything in that circle is dedicated and surrendered to God, the Revival will be on.' In other words, it's waiting for you and me.

In First Kings chapter 18, during the competition on Mount Carmel between Elijah and the 450 prophets of Baal, they got all worked up, crying out, yelling to Baal. Of course, nobody answered. Then, at a certain point, they started cutting themselves with stones, literally bleeding to get their god’s attention.

Remember when Jesus goes to Gadara and gets off the boat, he’s met by one or two demon-possessed men, depending on the Gospel you read. They identify as Legion, inhabited by a legion of demons. One of their attributes is living in the tombs, breaking shackles off himself, screaming, and cutting himself.

I was probably 10 years old, and I attended a funeral at a Lutheran Church here in Yorba Linda. My neighbor Scott’s father had been killed in a car accident, and I’ll never forget his wife uncontrollably weeping when the service was over, clinging to the casket, not wanting them to take it out of the church, almost being dragged behind it.

Years ago at camp, we were tent camping, and someone needed to ask me something. They thought I was in my tent taking a nap, so they stood outside calling, 'Pastor Bob, I just need to ask you a few questions.' But I wasn’t there—I was coming back from the river or store, and I saw them talking to an empty tent!

Here's an Egyptian scroll written at approximately the same time as Deuteronomy. To prevent gray hair, take blood from a black cat, mix it with the fat of a rattlesnake, and eat twice daily. Or to reverse baldness, take fat from a cat, a horse, a crocodile, a hippo, a snake, and an ibex, mix it together, and eat it—and if it’s a severe case, add a tooth of a donkey cooked in honey.

There's an interesting true story from history about Ivan the Great, the Tsar of Russia in the 15th century. He was so busy running his empire that he didn’t have time to find a wife, so his friends found him the daughter of the King of Greece to marry, forming an alliance between the two kingdoms. But there was a condition: Ivan had to become a member of the Greek Orthodox Church, and he brought 500 of his special armed forces with him who also had to be trained because they did everything the king did.

This is a true story. Ivan and 500 soldiers showed up for baptism in their uniforms, swords in hand, but the Greek Orthodox priests refused to baptize them because they were soldiers involved in bloodshed. So, they came up with a solution: all the men were baptized, but they held their swords up above the water, keeping them dry—literally, there’s a painting called the 'unbaptized arm,' meaning my whole life is given to God except this one area, my sword, because I’m still gonna use it.
If we did baptism that way today, there’d be people holding up their wallets or their credit cards, you know, keeping that one area from being surrendered to God.

RJ Lerno, known as God's businessman, created Earth-moving equipment during World War II, held over 300 patents, and became very wealthy. He and his wife gave away 90% of their income, living on just 10%, believing all riches belonged to God. He’d say, 'I shovel out the money and God shovels it back, but God has a bigger shovel.'

RJ Lerno also said to folks who think, 'Well, I want to get rich,' that if you give because it pays, it will not pay. In other words, if that’s your reason, you might as well forget it. It’s not about that.

You've heard the name John D. Rockefeller. At 33, he was a millionaire, and by 53, the world's first billionaire. But by then, he was a shell of a man—alopecia affected him, he looked like a mummy, his income was a million a week, yet he could only digest milk and crackers, couldn’t sleep, wouldn’t smile, and nothing in life meant anything to him.

When I go to Israel once a year—we’re going in March with about a hundred of you, by the way, I can’t wait—I know it’s in a different time zone, ten hours ahead of us. But for some reason, when I’m there, my thinking gets muddy, maybe because of jet lag, and I forget if it’s ten hours ahead or behind. I’ll call one of my sons or staff back home to tell them something I need done, and it’s the middle of the night—‘Hello, Mama, sorry, I got it wrong again!’

I had a close friend from Biola in the 1970s, a Bible major like me, on fire for the Lord. He was a passionate preacher and singer, invited me to preach at his Spanish-speaking church in Placentia, and I loved being around his energy. But a couple years after graduation, I ran into him, and the sparkle was gone from his eyes; he said he got married, faced troubles, and now works for his father-in-law at a jewelry store instead of going into ministry.

You know, when I was in high school, I owned stock—three shares of Levitz Furniture. It split three times before I bought, never after, a little over $100 worth, which was a lot of money back then. I’d pick up my dad’s newspaper every day—he bought all the papers in town—and I’d go straight to the stock market page to find Levitz, checking if it was up or down, getting excited about making a little money on my hundred bucks.

My grandkids ask lots of questions about heaven, and I don’t have all the answers. I just tell ‘em, ‘I don’t know, but it’s gonna be better than anything you can imagine.’ I’ve got God’s Word on that.

I love this song from years ago that says, ‘I can’t wait to see Jesus in His glory as He bursts from the sky. I can’t wait to be held in His arms and see the glimmer in His eye.’ It’s all about longing for that day when Jesus comes again.

George Muller was once asked later in his life, 'What is the secret of God using you so powerfully?' He said, 'There was a day when I died, utterly died.' As he spoke, he bent lower and lower toward the ground until he almost touched it, saying, 'I died to George Muller, his opinions, his preferences, his taste, and I died to the world, its approval or censure, even to the approval or blame of my brethren and friends. Since that day, I studied only to show myself approved to God.'

I drove through LA twice last week, and both times on the 605 near Rose Hills Cemetery, I saw these big billboards advertising it as 'voted America's best cemetery.' Now, where did they dig up those voters, I wanna know? I mean, is it a scale of one to ten, rate your experience here—ten being restful and peaceful, one being dirty and dark?

I have to share with you a very terrible secret because I'm the only one who's alive that knows it. When the missionaries first came to us in the Congo, my parents and the other people there, we didn't know if what they were saying was true or if we really believed it. And this is the terrible secret—my tribe poisoned many of them.

My youngest granddaughter Lilly is six, and you want to make her come alive, just talk to her about American Girl dolls. Becky and I took her to the American Girl store in LA, and she was outside of herself to be there. We told her we’re just looking, but she picked up a bitty baby doll and accessories, got in the cashier line, and we ended up buying it all.
You want to make my grandson Jonah come alive, just talk to him about superheroes or video games. Boy, his ears perk right up and he’s got a lot to say about that.

There's a moment that's pretty special in a wedding. We're all waiting until that 'dun duh duh duh' moment, and the bride comes in, looking better than she's ever looked or ever will look the rest of her life. That revelation moment of who you really are.

I remember being on stage with Greg Laurie at the Harvest Crusade years ago. He was preaching about heaven, saying there’ll be no sickness, no dying, no pain, and then he said, 'You’ll be able to eat whatever you want and you won’t get fat!' I thought, really, that’s the best thing we can say about heaven?
A girl was walking with her dad out at night. She looked up at the stars and said, 'Daddy, if the wrong side of heaven is this beautiful, I can’t wait to get to the right side.'

As a boy, I thought of heaven as a city with domes and spires and beautiful streets inhabited by angels. But when my little brother died, and then others, and eventually my own children, I began to think I had treasure in heaven myself. Now, with so many loved ones there, I sometimes think I know more people in heaven than I do on earth.

I'll never forget, I was in a car coming back from an academy graduation with the chief of police and two captains. I’m just a detective, way below their ranks, but I’d spent time with the chief, a Christian, talking and praying in his office. On the way home, I casually called him Hal, but I noticed the captains kept saying 'Chief,' giving me looks like, 'Hey, his name is Chief,' and it dawned on me I’d stopped treating him with the respect he was due because of our relationship.

Incense is a picture in the Bible, in the temple, of prayer. Revelation talks about how the prayers of the saints are mixed with the incense, and the picture was this: the priest would offer this sweet, holy incense, and from outside the temple, you’d see billows of smoke going up into heaven.

I remember I was in first grade when JFK was assassinated in 1963. The lunch lady came running through the campus, screaming and crying, 'They shot the president! They shot the president!' They put us on buses, sent us home, and it was traumatic, not just for a little five-year-old, but for the whole nation wondering, 'What's going to happen now? What does this mean? Who did this?'

Think of Gideon in Judges chapter six. Before God sent him to fight the Midianites with just 300 men and do this miraculous thing, God told him, 'Gideon, your dad has an idol in the backyard. You need to go tear it down tonight.'
God says I've cast your sins into the depths of the sea. In other words, they're not something I want you to dwell on. It's a place you can't imagine ever being or coming back from.

I think it's Corrie ten Boom who said God puts our sins in the depths of the ocean, then He posts a sign saying, 'No fishing allowed.' In other words, don't go fishing for somebody else's past sins or even your own.

Aren’t you glad you don’t have to remember every sin? I am glad. I could imagine if I said, 'Lord, let’s see, I kind of lost my temper, and I’ve been prideful,' and God says, 'Uh, we’re gonna be here a long time.'

Moses's mom wanted to protect him from being exposed to the world, but she discovers it's not possible. There are some parents in the church today who are convinced they can do what Moses's mom couldn't do. I'm gonna keep my kids from ever being exposed to this wicked world.

I strongly believe this, that children are one of God's primary ways to test our faith. Every time I've ever said that, I always get laughs, and I don't know why. It's either people that don't have kids or do, but either way, ha ha.

Herod sends out soldiers to kill every baby boy in Bethlehem who's two years of age and under. He’s thinking, 'I've got to kill this child who's being born King of the Jews.' So, they kill every male child.
God’s one step ahead of Herod. He gave a dream to Joseph in the night, saying, 'Arise, take the child and flee to Egypt.'
We have kind of a picture here of an older sister concerned about her little brother, no doubt, but watching mom and dad's decision to put him in this little ark and to put him out on the river.

Humanly speaking, probably the last place I'd want to put my son to keep him safe is the place where they're supposed to be killing all the kids. I'd want to go as far away from that as possible. It's very counterintuitive to put him where they're gonna kill him, but that's where God directed he should go.
Here we see the mother, she basically lets her son go. I want him to be saved, but I can't save him. I've got to let them live, got to trust you, God.

Peter says we've left everything, what's for us? If you give up your unsaved boyfriend, ladies, God's gonna have 100 guys calling you up to ask you out on a date? Or you quit your job because they want you to be unethical, you'll have 100 recruiters calling the next week? I don't think that's what it means, but it does mean there will be losses as believers, yet in the end, man, it'll all be worth it a hundred times over.
Pharaoh's daughter named him Moses, a word that means to draw, 'cause she drew him out of the water. In English, we would've just called him Drew. I'm not joking, that's really what the word means.

Years ago, tires had more rubber in them, and one problem was trying to bury them in landfills. Because of the air in the tires, over time, they’d come back to the surface. They’d cover them over, build homes, and 20 or 30 years later, tires would start popping up in people’s yards.

Moses was educated in all the learning of the Egyptians, and he was a man of power in words and deeds. Egypt was advanced in their learning, and in fact, some of the ancient techniques of the Egyptians are still advanced—we don’t even know how they did what they did.

The Egyptians didn’t believe the earth was flat as many cultures did in the ancient world; they believed it was round. They actually calculated the exact distance between the Earth and the Sun back 4,000 years ago, and they knew chemistry way ahead of everyone else.

I remember being called by a guy in our church 20 years ago. He said, 'I need to talk to you, big guy. Mine are gonna come back with something I need to explain—it's gonna show that I’ve murdered somebody.'

I love studying the book of Job. Most of you know Job, but there was this drama between God and the devil at the beginning of the book, challenging the reality of Job's faith. Satan says, 'If you stop blessing him so much, he wouldn’t believe in you; in fact, he’d curse you,' and God gives Satan permission to test him.

I just turned twenty-one thousand eight hundred and seventy-nine days old today. Every time I say that, people start clapping and come up to say happy birthday afterwards, thinking it’s a birthday. But that’s how many days old I am, though even that’s wrong because I spent 273 days in the womb, maybe more since my mom had help having me, so maybe I was late, making me twenty-two thousand one hundred and fifty-two days old—older than I look!

Listen to this, the Sun, our Sun, protects us from cosmic rays and dust from beyond the solar system by enveloping us in the heliosphere, a bubble of solar wind that extends past Pluto. These cosmic rays would damage the ozone layer, and interstellar dust could dim sunlight and trigger an ice age if it wasn’t for the Sun. I know people try to shield from our Sun because of skin cancer, but literally, our Sun provides protection as well as power.

I had two dear friends who, completely separate, got COVID, went into the hospital, were on ventilators. One, three hours afterwards, went home to be with the Lord, and the other, a few days later, was home for Christmas, an answered prayer.

You know, the mailman’s motto is, 'Neither snow nor rain nor heat nor gloom of night stays these couriers from the swift completion of their appointed rounds.' And I was thinking, as we’re here tonight, neither rain nor cold nor Christmas cleanup or fear of Omicron will stop some of you from coming to church, and I’m glad.

I was reminded years ago of a story from a communist country where believers met underground for worship because it was against the law. While they were worshiping, two armed soldiers came in, guns drawn, and ordered everyone to leave or be shot. Most left, but a couple said, 'We're not leaving, we're gonna worship the Lord regardless,' and the soldiers took off their coats and said, 'Good, we're Christians too, we just don't want to worship with half-hearted Christians.'

Remember when Moses got mad at the children of Israel? They were complaining about being thirsty, no water to drink. The first time, God said, 'Smite the rock,' and Moses did, water came out. Later, it happened again, but Moses was ticked off. God said, 'Just speak to the rock this time, water will come out.' But Moses, angry, said, 'Shall I bring forth water from this rock, you rebels?' and he struck it instead.

Remember, Moses smote the rock twice, but the rock, according to 1 Corinthians 10, is a type of Christ. Christ was to be smitten once, dying on the cross for us just once. Moses lost his temper, and because of that, God said, 'Hey, you have not treated me as holy,' and he lost his trip to the Holy Land.

God is extremely patient with the immature, aren't you glad I am? He doesn't get ticked off like Moses did. Moses was mad at the people, thinking God was mad too, but God wasn’t; they were just thirsty and immature.

Just like Peter, James, and John wanted to call down fire on the Samaritans, saying, 'Hey man, they won't let you stay overnight here, let's call down fire, that's biblical.' But Jesus says, 'You do not know what spirit you're of.'

It's an amazing thing, children get to an age where they feel safe to confess stuff they did growing up. My sons, who are adults now with their own families, don't mind telling us about when they stole our car as teenagers before they had driver's licenses, driving around the neighborhood. I'm still trying to figure out how to punish them for that, but I'm just kidding because it's funny years later.

Guess what, it's not just the wicked, it's all of us. That's why David said, 'In sin my mother conceived me.' In other words, from the moment I was conceived, I had the capacity to rebel against God, I had a sin nature, and all I've done since coming forth from the womb is prove it with the way I've acted.

God sent a prophet to King Asa and said, 'That was sin. You should have sought the Lord. Why didn't you seek God? He gave you victory years ago against the Cushites when you knew you couldn’t fight them, so you sought the Lord. But where’s that spirit now?'

God allowed King Asa to become diseased in his feet, a horrible disease. But the Bible says, even though he was diseased, he didn’t seek God for healing. He sought the doctors instead, leaving the Lord out.

Here's what God is saying through Jeremiah to Israel: I remember the devotion of your youth, the love of your betrothals, when you followed after me in the wilderness through a land not sown. I remember when I saved you out of Egypt, those first few days and years when you went after me like we were first dating, engaged.

I've shared before about that elderly couple in their car. The wife, after seeing a young couple close together in the car ahead, says to her husband, 'I wish we could be the way we used to be.' He looks at her and says, 'I haven't moved, I'm still right in the same place I've always been, come on over.'

I remember the first time my parents trusted me to be home alone. I felt pretty grown up, but then a stranger knocked on the door, a young guy with paint on his hands, saying, ‘We’re painting address numbers on curbs for just a dollar, can we do yours?’ I had to tell him, ‘I can’t give permission because I don’t own this house,’ and he walked away frustrated.

There's an old song by the Gaithers that says, 'You will notice we say brother and sister around here, it's because we're a family and these are so dear. When one has a heartache, we all share the tears and rejoice in each victory in this family so dear.'

We've got people at our church right now who are sick, some who've had strokes in different stages of recovery, and others who've lost loved ones and are grieving. I thank God when I hear of somebody who's lost their spouse and they say, 'It's been the hardest thing in my life, but God has helped me in a way that I can't imagine going through it without the family of God.'

My wife received the Lord at three years of age. You might say, 'Is that possible?' Well, that's what she says—she gave her life to Christ, knowing she needed Jesus even at three, realizing if He came back, she wasn’t gonna go.

God told His people in Deuteronomy about hygiene, saying, 'When you gotta go to the bathroom, go out of the camp, not in it, and cover it up. I walk in the camp, and I don’t wanna see anything unclean among you.'

I remember a single parent mom who had a little 4-year-old son. She came one Sunday night and said, 'I was asking my son which church he wanted to go to since we’re checking out a few. He said to me, I want to go to the Awesome God Church!'

There was a missionary on the field for a while, using his skills for the Lord’s work. Standard Oil searched for someone with certain qualities, found him, and offered him a huge salary. After a couple of months, he called them and said, 'It’s not gonna work out. The salary is too big, but the job isn’t big enough. I don’t want to live my life for this after living for the Lord.'
There was a headhunter for a company who decided he’d make every applicant feel uncomfortable as they sat down in their chair. Some of us have met folks like that, but that was his thing.

In Ephesus, where Timothy was pastoring, they had the Temple of Artemis, one of the seven wonders of the world. It had a hundred and twenty-seven pillars, 60 feet high, made of dazzling marble, many encrusted with jewels and overlaid with gold. Everybody in that city knew about pillars, and just as those pillars testified to the error of false religion, Paul says the Church of Jesus Christ is to be a testimony to the divine revelation of genuine truth.

Years ago, Hank Snow wrote a song called 'My Religion's Not Old-Fashioned.' I love the words he said, 'My religion's not old-fashioned, but it's real and genuine too, and to make for today as they did in my Lord's time.' Modern days don't make a difference.

When a jeweler wants to really show off a diamond, they put it under special lights and against black velvet, something very dark. If you want to appreciate the light, you have to put it against something dark. As this world gets darker, it’s our chance, our time to shine like never before.

For me, that was in 1971, in a little cabin at a junior high retreat. Most of the people at that camp didn’t know that the most important thing that happened, as far as I was concerned, that weekend was I came into the kingdom of God.

Jesus Christ, when he comes into your life, will never ever ever leave you or forsake you. I'm going on 46 years with him, and I can say every day, thank you that you have never left me and you never will, but you will take me home to be with you someday.

Angel brought up a good point at lunchtime. He said, 'It's rocks cry out in worship, so will I.' God created rocks to be rocks, and they do a good job at being rocks—by their nature, they scream God's glory.

Bless Fest happens every year at our church at Thanksgiving. It's the most attended volunteer thing we do. I think we had 800 volunteers on Thanksgiving come out to serve the homeless last year, and we're expecting more homeless people to be able to come this year.

Aaron's sons, Eliezer and Ithamar, were disobedient to the Lord. They took the role of high priest, a role they shouldn't have taken, and the Bible says fire came out from the presence of God and they died suddenly. Here are guys who weren’t out smoking crack or robbing banks, they’re in the ministry, and they died because they didn’t treat God as holy.
I think of Job, who lost all of his children on the same day. Now that’s hard to fathom, it’s hard to even imagine.
David lost his firstborn son that he had with Bathsheba, and he grieved. The people around him thought he might take his own life because of how grieved he was.

I spoke to a woman and her husband coming up on Sunday, and she had tears in her eyes. She said, 'We’ve never met, but I wanted to meet you because we’re moving to Nebraska. We’ve just enjoyed it here so much.'

I remember with my friends Fred and Carol, we were junior high friends, and then Fred and Carol were dating in high school. We could tell they were in love, and we’d go down to Calvary Chapel Costa Mesa for concerts and Bible studies, taking our friends down there. You know, Calvary Chapel would have about twenty-five hundred to three thousand young people every Saturday night at these concerts, more than could fit in the room.

I remember this gal, not sure if she was engaged yet, sitting up there. A total stranger came up to her and said, 'I feel like the Lord is telling me that you're the one.' She held up her ring and said, 'I'm spoken for,' and he just walked off.

When you leave a church, if it doesn't hurt, it wasn't healthy. I describe it like velcro ripping, you know that noise. Even when God's in it, moving you on, it should hurt, and if it doesn't, that's not a good sign.

I have three sons, all adults now, but can you imagine if one of them, at 5, 8, or 10 years old, disappeared one night? Do you think Becky and I would just say, 'Well, we still got two, probably joined another family down the street, they’ll be fine'? Oh no, it doesn’t work that way in a family; you get close enough to know what’s going on in each other’s lives, and it matters when someone’s not there, even for one day.

The blessing is like the oil that comes down on the head of Aaron, saturating the whole body. It’s a one-time anointing that affects the rest of his life, a type and picture of the baptism of the Holy Spirit that happens once in your life.
It’s like that dew of Mount Hermon that daily saturates the mountains, allowing them to flourish. That dew, baby, it’s every day. God shows up with that refreshment daily through the Holy Spirit.

Listen, our church was small most of the time till a few years ago when God decided to bless us and grow us. I love what God's doing here, but I know He has to do something different because it used to be you'd walk in the door, come for a month, and everybody knew you.

I read this account when I was a police chaplain. A chaplain went out with a police officer on his shift, and the officer opened his heart, saying, 'Man, my life’s a mess, my wife’s leaving me, my kids won’t talk to me, I might be losing my job, I’ve got lots of personal problems.' At the end of the night, as the chaplain got out of the cop car, the officer turned to him and said, 'Thank you, I was beginning to think that hope was a girl I knew in the third grade.'

You know, it’s funny, I was studying ahead and I’m ready to preach next week’s message on chapter seven, but I’ve been talking to people about tonight’s message as though it’s next week’s. I’m going, ‘Oh, this is happening in the past,’ and they’re like, ‘Oh, really?’ So, if I was talking to you, just throw that out, that’s next week.

In Jeremiah chapter 35, God tells Jeremiah to bring the sons of Jonadab into the temple, put wine in front of them, and say, 'Drink wine.' They respond, 'We don’t drink wine, even though others can, because our fathers, our ancestors, said not to drink wine and to live in tents, not houses.' God points out how they honor their earthly, imperfect father, while His people don’t honor Him, commending their reverence for their dad’s wisdom.

I think sometimes of those people, maybe even some here, where let’s say a wife gets cancer and because of chemotherapy, she loses her hair. Her husband decides, 'I’m cutting my hair off too.' It’s not required, but it’s his way of saying, 'I love you, and I want you to know I’m in this with you.'

There was a dead young man, and Jesus touched the coffin. You don’t do that as a Nazarite, by the way. Then, when the synagogue ruler came and said, 'My daughter’s sick unto death,' and they told him she’s already dead, Jesus said, 'Let’s go,' touched the little girl, and said, 'Talitha Kumi, I say to you, little girl, arise.'

When I started dating the woman who would become my wife, I started caring about how clean my car was inside and out. I’d polish the car before picking her up and vacuum it out. She was convinced I was a clean freak, though I’ve since popped that balloon.

I can recall having long hair when I was in high school, walking by a little 7-Eleven near a barber shop. Some total stranger, obviously a barber, looked at me and assumed stuff because of my hair. Back in the 60s and 70s, long hair meant to some older folks that you’re a hippie or rebellious, though sometimes it was just a style.

God imagines sometimes someone’s gonna make this commitment, try to live it out, but then it’s gonna get violated. You know, someone’s gonna die, they had a heart attack, and you’d have to do CPR. God gives us the opportunity to say, if that happens, you’re defiled, you didn’t live out your commitment, but you can start all over again as though it was day one.
Let’s talk about Samson, because Samson was a Nazarite. He insisted on doing what he wanted rather than serving God, and there are a number of ways we see this if you study his life.

Jesus said, 'I will not drink of this fruit of the vine from now on until that day when I drink it anew with you in my Father’s Kingdom.' Very interesting, I will drink it again, but not until then, after my consecration is completed.

John Courson spoke to about 300 of our men a few years ago up at Twin Peaks, shared about alcohol and how many Christians struggle with the freedom to drink. He said something I’ve never heard before but think everybody should consider: Jesus said, 'I’m not going to drink again until I drink it with you in heaven,' so why don’t you make that commitment?
Remember when God introduces Himself in the Old Testament to Moses? Moses says, 'Well, who should I say sent me?' God said, 'You can tell them who sent you: I Am.'

I'm the youngest of five, and one of my earlier memories, when I was about six, is my parents leaving us alone for a bit. They went to the store, thinking they could trust us with my older brothers and sisters. Well, that was a mistake, because we decided to have a pillow fight the moment they were gone.

We were having a great time in the living room, beating up on each other with pillows, until one of my sisters pinched me. I swung hard at her, she ducked, and I hit a lamp behind her, smashing it into a thousand pieces. Suddenly, the pillow fight was over, and my siblings said, 'Bobby, you're in so much trouble when Mom and Dad get home!'

I was so frightened after breaking the lamp that I walked out of the house, halfway down the hill we lived on, and just sat on the curb waiting for Mom and Dad to come home. I didn’t know what I was going to say or how they’d react, but I knew they’d be mad. When I saw their Chevy Malibu pulling up, I started crying, and my dad rolled down the window and said, 'Bobby, Bobby, what’s wrong?'

We were having a pillow fight, and I broke the lamp. My dad said, 'That's it!' I said, 'Yeah,' and he asked, 'Are you okay? Everybody else okay?' When we said everybody's fine, he gave me a big hug and said, 'I don't care about the lamp. We can get another lamp. We care about you.'

I remember one minister, true story, in the church I attended, said people ask me if they should tithe their net or their gross income. I tell them it depends on whether you want net or gross blessings.

Remember when people came and asked Jesus about the tower that fell on those guys, and Pilate had killed some people? They asked, 'Do you think these guys were worse sinners, and that’s why that tragedy happened to them?' Jesus said, 'I tell you no, but you too will perish unless you repent.'
You can take a jelly donut and you can't tell what kind of jelly's in it until you run over it with your car. Then you'll know.

True story from the time of the East-West Berlin separation, before the Berlin Wall was built. One night, some East Germans got a truck full of trash and dumped it on the West German side of the border.

Back in 1875, there was a man named Matthew Webb, the first to swim the English Channel in 22 hours. He later heard about a deadly spot above Niagara Falls no one could swim past and survive, so he said, 'I'll go over there and show them how one can really swim.' On July 24th, 1883, crowds watched as he swam out, was pulled over the falls, and died, and they named a nearby marker Redemption Point.

You ever just imagine what it’ll be like to worship the Lord in heaven? I mean, Revelation talks about myriads of angels, hundreds of millions, worshiping Him, and the saints bowing down. If you think worshiping in a congregation or stadium is awesome, what will that be like?

I remember hearing a song by a band called Children of the Day, nearly 50 years ago. The words went, 'There's a life of joy and happiness, and it's waiting just for you, a life of love that you've been longing for with a perfect ending too.' As a young Christian, those lyrics caught my attention and taught me that God had a personal plan for my life.
I was moved to tears thinking, Lord, where would I be if not for you? I was in the back seat of a police car in handcuffs as a Christian.

In Revelation 1:15, John hears the voice of the Lord, and it sounded like the voice of many waters. Picture Niagara or any place where streams converge to create a deafening waterfall. The idea is that when the Lord speaks, He often uses different streams—maybe a devotional, a song on the radio, or a friend’s story—to say the same thing so it’s clear to us.

When I was a police officer and chaplain, there was this homeless guy with nowhere to go. They called me, 'Hey Bob, come in.' So, we took him into our home, but I told him, 'You can stay here, but just so you know, we go to church on Sunday morning, Sunday night, and Wednesday night. You’re welcome, but this is what we do as a family.'

After I graduated Seminary, my wife Becky and I knew the Lord was calling us into ministry somewhere. We waited on the Lord for about a year, praying, 'Lord, where do you want us to go?' I’d look at lists of churches all over the country needing pastors, open to going anywhere, but we got no direction until the Lord put on my heart to start a Calvary Chapel in Placentia, which was not in our plans at all.

I was on my way to Seminary, sitting at the light at Chapman and Kramer, and suddenly I remembered this girl, Becky Olsen, who used to work at the Placentia library years ago. I hadn’t thought of her, we weren’t dating or anything, but I felt this weird urge to go check if she was still there. So I went in, not even needing a library since I have a big one at school, and asked, ‘Hey, does Becky Olsen still work here?’ and they said, ‘Yeah, in fact, she does.’

Listen, First Corinthians 2:9 says, 'Things which eye has not seen and ear has not heard, and which have not entered into the heart of man.' That applies to heaven, but in context, it has nothing to do with heaven—it’s about His will for you right now. You can’t imagine how good God’s plan is, so if you can dream up a wonderful life for yourself, God has something even better.

It was years ago at a sunrise service on Easter. The pastor was waiting for the organist to start the first song, but she wasn’t there. Right at the last second, she slipped into place, played the song, and later apologized for sleeping in since it was so early.
The next year on Easter, the pastor called the organist ahead of time. When she answered, he said, 'He has risen, and you better be too!'

I heard a story years ago of a man and his son driving on a warm day out through the countryside. The little boy, maybe six or seven, had already known from earlier in his life the pain of being stung.
Have you stood at the rim and looked at the Grand Canyon? If not, you need to get there. It’s amazing, no question about it.

Have you looked through the Hubble’s telescope at the 2 trillion stars God threw into this universe when He created it? That’s just the observable universe. What’s in the unobservable universe? You can’t see it; it’s beyond that, spectacular and awesome.

I was talking to a man after the sunrise service. He said, 'Some people tried to ask me to go forward, and I told them I wasn’t ready, I didn’t want to go.' I said, 'Listen, if God is real, if Christ really died for you, if He’s the Son of God and He rose again from the dead, and He could come into your life...'
By the way, that's why baptisms were always public. They didn't do baptisms in hot tubs or bathtubs; they did them in rivers, publicly, where other people could see your profession of faith.

Hey, Jesus can handle a large crowd of people that want to meet Him. Paul says in First Corinthians over 500 people saw Jesus at one time. So if 500 of you wanna come, He's already handled that; He’s able to meet you personally.

It’s interesting when the first one met Him—Mary. She was weeping in the garden, thinking He was the gardener, and they had moved her beloved Savior. But He sure recognized her, and then He said her name.

Can I tell you, that’s moving to me because that’s the way the Lord always works. He calls people very specific—Saul, Saul, why are you persecuting Me? He knows what you’re going through; He’s drawing you to Himself, and He’ll say your name personally.

You know, I think about that movie, maybe you've read the book, Mr. Phillips. Remember that true story of Captain Phillips back in 2009? He was the captain of a big cargo ship, captured by Somali pirates, held captive in a lifeboat out of gas, and for three days, these poorly armed, poorly trained pirates held an 800 million dollar U.S. Navy destroyer at bay.
I am reminded that I grew up going to a church where they said it every Easter. I don't think we've said it yet today, but let's make sure we do. He is risen!

I had a friend years ago who attended this church. He had kidney problems, was on dialysis, and without it, he would’ve died. They were waiting for a kidney transplant, and his doctor told him, ‘Until you get that new kidney, you’re not doing good,’ even though my friend thought he was okay relatively speaking.

Peter and John walk into the temple, fix their gaze on this lame man who’s been there every day, begging. Peter says, 'Silver and gold have we none, but such as we have, give we thee. In the name of Jesus Christ of Nazareth, I say to you, rise and walk.' Peter took him by the hand, lifted him up, and his ankles and feet were totally healed. He went into the temple—probably the first time in his life—walking and leaping, praising God!

I love this story of a man and his son. The little boy had been stung by a bee at an early age and almost died because he was allergic. The doctors warned him to stay away from bees, but one summer day, while driving with the windows down, a bee got into the car. The boy was terrified, yelling, 'Daddy, Daddy, a bee!' His dad reached over, caught it midair, and when the bee started buzzing again, he said, 'Don't be afraid, son, I've taken the sting for you. It cannot hurt you.'

There was an atheist giving a speech in a park, putting down Christianity. A man, the town drunk who got radically converted and is now sober, walks up peeling an orange, eats it, and asks, 'Is the orange I just ate sweet or sour?' The atheist says, 'How could I know? I never tasted it,' and the man replies, 'Exactly, and that’s why you can’t know anything about Jesus Christ because you’ve never experienced Him, but I have, and He’s alive.'

Think of what Jesus said in Revelation 3:20, 'Behold, I stand at the door and I knock. If anyone hears my voice and opens the door, I'll come in.' The God of the universe stands outside—it's actually the church of Laodicea, His house, His people, but He's on the outside.
Reminds me of the Flintstones, you know, why is Fred outside his own house? Well, it's his house, but the cat locked him out. We know the story.
I like what someone once said, 'We're to be fishers of men.' Basically, he said, 'You catch them, I'll clean them.'

The night I prayed to receive Christ, I didn't know I needed to, I didn't know I could, I didn't know I should. I'd gone to church my whole life, believed everything, even went to Bible college and seminary, but nothing changed in my theology until that night.

Somebody asked me a very important question. He had never led a person to Christ his whole life, but he started witnessing to me. I’m so grateful the guy was pushing me because I wouldn’t be here today if he wasn’t.

There were four of us in that cabin—my friend and two adults. All three of them are in heaven now; I’m the only one left. But over 50 years ago, that night he asked, ‘Have you ever received Christ?’ and I said, ‘No.’

Everybody that Jesus called in the Gospels to believe, He did it publicly. He said, 'If you confess me before men, I'll confess you before my Father in heaven. If you deny me before men, try to keep this little secret, I'll deny you before my Father who is in heaven.'

That's why baptisms in the Bible are always public. You never see baptism in the Bible in a hot tub or a bathtub—always in streams and rivers, always public. Because your profession of faith is, as Jesus died for me openly, I'm going to live for Him openly.
Lord, like these women who took the evidence they had and obeyed in faith and just took a few steps, and then you revealed yourself, will you do it again right now?

You know, the day my wife and I got married, I remember we were in the elevator at the Regency Hotel in San Francisco, and she looked at me as we were going up and said, 'We're married!' It was like, can you believe it? It's really happened!

I went and saw the Mario movie with my son yesterday, and when Mario powers up with the star, my childhood comes rushing back to me. I'm like, 'What does this have to do with my life? Why am I feeling so emotional right now?'
I believe God used youth leaders in ways far beyond what we could ever imagine. What if we have the next Pastor Bob in a youth group? Who knows!

My first experience with Calvary Chapel was in 1973, a long time ago. I had heard there was a Christian rock and roll band playing on a Saturday night at Calvary Costa Mesa in a tent. I went down there with my friends, and it was Love Song; it was a great concert, awesome, with about 2,000 people, mostly my age or a bit older, and we sat on the grass because we didn’t get there early enough for a seat.

About a week or two later, I was alone in my car, and I felt like God spoke to my heart. He said, 'Here’s what’s different about those people at church—they are in love with Jesus, they don’t mind talking or shouting about it, they want to celebrate their love for the Lord, and that’s something you have a hard time doing, Bob.'

As the conviction of the Holy Spirit fell upon me, guess where I was the next Saturday and the next Saturday for years? I attended Calvary Chapel, every concert, and brought so many friends from our high school. We didn’t know how to share the gospel, but we’d bring them there, and pastors like Tom Stipe would give the gospel message.

There was this Ultra Bright toothpaste commercial, and their tagline was, 'How's your love life?' The idea was that Ultra Bright gives you sex appeal, and they kept asking people, 'How's your love life?'

Someone said words are kind of like coins; when they've been in circulation a long time, they can lose their value. You hear people say, 'We don't need to get married because we love one another,' and I find that kind of bizarre.
Jesus said, 'Hey Peter, go take a fishing pole, go down to the Sea of Galilee, take out a fish. The first fish that comes up will have a coin in its mouth. Go pay the tax lest we stumble them.'

Many years ago, our church was in a small sanctuary on Orangethorpe for about 17 years. I had a friend, Bob Hendricks, older than me, who used to take me to lunch when I was a detective at Placentia Police Department. Bob showed up to our small church of maybe 125 people, and I’ll never forget, he came in a suit.

My friend Bob wears a suit every Sunday, and I asked him why, since at Calvary Chapel most folks come casual. He said, 'I do this so if someone visits who doesn’t know we’re casual, they won’t feel out of place. They can look over, see me, and think, well, at least I’m not the only idiot.'
Bob used to stand by the door, and everybody had to get by him. You were gonna get a hug whether you liked it or not. It wasn’t because I told him to do it; it was just the love of God in him.

I told Bob, 'I’ve seen real growth in your life.' He said, 'Well, there was a book I read called The Greatest Thing in the World by Henry Drummond, a study of First Corinthians 13 about love. As I studied the love of God, He started pouring love into me and through me.'

D.L. Moody said of his early preaching, 'I preached God hated sinners, and He was standing behind them with a double-edged sword ready to cut off their heads.' But when a young man, Henry Morehouse, preached in Chicago while I was away, my wife told me he preaches different—he says God loves sinners. I returned, heard him preach night after night on John 3:16, and I never knew till then that God loved us so much; my heart began to thaw out, I couldn’t keep back the tears.

Moody said, 'I took up that word love, and I don’t know how many weeks I spent studying the passages where it occurs, till at last I couldn’t help loving people. I’d been feeding on God’s love so long that I was anxious to do good to everybody I came in contact with. I got so full of it, it ran out my fingers.'
Holding a grudge is like letting someone live rent-free in your head. You got somebody living there.

I've noticed this about me, I'm very merciful to myself. When others drive too fast, the cop comes out of me—where's the cop when you need him? Idiots driving this way, running red lights, I'll say, 'Becky, did you see that?' But when I do it, oh, I'm so kind to myself, 'I timed it wrong, I meant to stop, I gassed it and still didn't make it, oh sorry.'
Like DL Moody said, fill us with love where it's coming out of us, we can't help but love the people around us.

You know, I was thinking this morning about how short our life is. The older you get, the more you realize it’s gonna be shorter still. I mean, a lot of us have lived longer on this Earth than we’re gonna live in these bodies, and that’s kind of a weird thought.

Somebody supposedly, when William Carey had the desire to send people out to the foreign mission field to share the gospel with the heathen, stood up and said, 'Young man, sit down. If God wants to save the heathen, He could do it without you. We don’t need you.'

Years ago, a man by the name of Don Francisco wrote a whole song about the first question God asks in the Bible, just three words in Genesis 3:9. Here are some of the words: 'Unashamed and naked in a garden that had never seen the rain, rulers of a kingdom full of joy, never marred by any pain.'

Just like Moses said when God sent him to save the Jews, 'Here am I, send somebody else. Send thy message by whomever thou wilt besides me.' I just don’t feel qualified, I don’t feel capable, I don’t have the right heart.

Many of you saw the movie 'The Jesus Revolution,' which I think was outstanding. I hope if there's anybody left on the planet who didn't see it, you will go see it. But one thing, in my opinion, didn't tell the whole story about the Jesus movement in Southern California, though it did a great job overall.

Greg Laurie came out and told us after we watched the preview, about a scene where Chuck hands me the keys to the building. He said, 'Ah, that never happened. That's just for the story,' but most of it was pretty accurate.

If you remember the movie, Chuck's daughter brings home Lonnie Frisbee, and his dad Chuck is not excited about that at all. Kay in the movie isn't too excited about it either. Now, that may have been the case, but there's more to the story.

In the 1960s, Southern California beaches were littered with hippies searching for the meaning of life through free love, psychedelic drugs, and communal living. One day, a pastor's wife went to the beach, and that's where this story kinda began.

Mary Booth never intended to be a missionary. She was just serving the needy and poor in London when God spoke to her, saying, 'Will you go to India?' She spent 35 years there in prayer and evangelistic ministry to women and children, seeing hundreds saved.

Mary Booth wrote this prayer that I love: 'Oh for a heart that is burdened, infused with a passion to pray. Oh for a stirring within me, oh for His power each day. Oh for a heart like my Savior, who being in agony prayed such caring for others.'

Leonard Ravenhill, never a man who sugar-coated anything, said, 'Jehovah's Witnesses don't believe in hell, and neither do most Christians today. Christians spend more money on dog food than missions.'
Spurgeon said, 'Millions have never heard of Jesus. We ought not to ask, can I prove that I ought to go, but can I prove that I ought not to go.'

Josh McDowell, who spoke to college campuses all over the world giving evidence for the resurrection of Christ and evangelizing, said, 'Too many young people, and I think too many people, say things like, if the Lord ever called me to the mission field, I'd go, or if the Lord opens the doors, I'll go.' He said, frankly, I don't think that's the right prayer because Jesus, two thousand years ago, opened the doors and said, go into all the world.

There's a movie Disney put out in 1937, Snow White and the seven dwarves. In that movie, there's a scene where the dwarves are in the diamond mine, and they're singing the song, 'Hi ho, hi ho, it's off to work we go.' Some of you have heard that before.

Years later, probably 30 or 40 years ago, I saw a bumper sticker that said, 'I owe, I owe, so off to work I go.' I think every Christian, if they could have it, would have a bumper sticker that says, 'I know, I know, so that's why I'm going to work.' I know the Lord, I know why I'm here, I know my purpose.
All of these missionaries were in attendance here, with the exception of my friend in Cuba who I led to the Lord in 1990 and started Calvary Chapel of Havana.

Paul told Timothy, 'Stir up the gift that is in you.' There was a word of prophecy concerning Timothy, and it had kind of just gotten laid to the side. Maybe you’re asking, 'Lord, confirm that calling in my life, stir it up again.'

I was talking to a couple last night, first time coming to church. They were waiting in line to meet me at the downtown Anaheim church at the Bible study, and I asked, 'How can I pray for you?' They said, 'Please pray for provision, we need help.'

Notice how the Lord engaged this woman at the well, asking her for a drink. She said, 'You Jews and we Samaritans, we don’t get along, so why are you asking me?' But the Lord told her, 'If you only knew, I could give you a drink where you will not thirst anymore.'

I was talking to a friend the other day, and he was showing me all this restoration he's doing to his motorcycle. He found this motorcycle that, to the previous owner, was just trash, sitting there collecting dust. But my friend saw the treasure in it, and he pursued fixing it, cleaning the carburetor, to make that thing run.

When I came to the Lord in 1992, I said, 'Lord, I want to find out if these things are true, the things I heard about you.' Let me tell you, I started reading the Word, reading the Scriptures like there’s no tomorrow, and that’s how I began my relationship with the Lord.

When the angel Gabriel came to Daniel in the Book of Daniel, he said, 'Daniel, you are beloved in heaven.' When I read that for the first time, I said, 'Lord, I want to be known by you, I want you to know me, and I want to know you.'
Jesus said, 'Behold, I stand at the door and knock. If any man hears my voice and opens the door, I’ll come in and we’ll have dinner together.' It’s not about the food, it’s about the fellowship.

I remember hearing about a wealthy Christian woman down in the South, a friend of Jimmy Carter. She had famous people stay in her mansion, including Jimmy Carter and his team during his campaign. After the election, a non-Christian neighbor asked who was the most famous person to stay in her home, and when she said Jimmy Carter, the friend replied, 'Ah, you're a Christian, I thought you'd say Jesus.' She responded, 'Oh no, Jesus has never stayed as a guest in my home; He lives here.'

I remember when the Word really changed my life. I had prayed that week before that God would have all of my life, totally surrendered to Him. That night, as I walked down the hall to watch my shows, the Spirit of God said, 'Go read.'

In Mark 6:48, it says Jesus saw the disciples straining at the oars on the Sea of Galilee during a storm, and about the fourth watch of the night, between 3 and 6 a.m., He came to them walking on the sea. Notice this, He intended to pass by them. What’s that about? Where was He going?
Remember when David wanted a place to build an altar, and the guy says, 'I’ll give you the lamb,' and David said, 'Oh no, I won’t worship God with what costs me nothing. I’ll pay full price for it.'

Abraham offered these angels and the Lord, who were just three strangers at this point, a little water and a piece of bread. But instead, what he brings are three full orders of pancakes, fresh milk, and veal cutlets—the best of the herd, getting his wife to make some really good stuff.
I think of that woman who wept at Jesus’s feet, but then she poured out the most precious possession she had.

I look at Abraham, and he says he's just gonna bring a little bread, a little water, but his intentions are clearly different. It's like he wants to surprise the guests, can't wait to bring out this feast and watch how they react. Little bread? This is hot! Little water? This is milk and filet mignon!
Have you ever had this conversation, 'What do you think heaven's gonna be like?' I’ve always wanted to fly. Had a couple dreams where I could fly, it was amazing, and I’d like to fly in heaven.

I always tell my grandkids, if you can imagine it, it's better than that. Whatever you can imagine, heaven’s gonna be better. You think you’ve imagined how good it’ll be, but it’s better than what you and I could ever ask for.
The tree, I think, is an incredible type and picture of the cross. If you want to stay in fellowship with the Lord, then you're gonna need to take a stand in the presence of the Lord at the tree.

Maybe you've heard me share it, I love this story. It was supposedly a true story about people who lived out here in the West before culture and society moved in. There was so much untamed land that when fires broke out, like they have in our state not long ago, there was really nothing you could do but run.

Her name was Fanny Crosby, lived in the 19th century. She became blind as an infant due to a quack doctor’s treatment, yet she wrote over 9,000 hymns like 'Blessed Assurance' and 'To God Be the Glory.' At eight years old, she wrote, 'Oh what a happy soul I am, although I cannot see, I am resolved that in this world contented I will be.'
One time, a well-meaning pastor said to Fanny Crosby, 'I think it’s a great pity that the Master did not give you sight when He showered you with so many other gifts.'
You're pretty lost when God has to use your drug dealer to reach you, right?

I was in the hospital, and the doctor said, 'You had less than a third of the blood you’re supposed to have. There’s no reasonable reason you should be alive. We’re baffled.' And I’m like, 'I know why I’m alive. It’s so I could tell you about Jesus.' I shared the gospel with this 80-year-old, highly intelligent, successful man who’d never heard it before, maybe the only time in his life. My pain and circumstances gave me that opportunity.

I’m getting on a bus since I can’t drive because of seizures, and this guy comes running up, excited, yelling, 'You’re Joel McGuire!' I’m apprehensive, like, 'What’s this guy want? Is he serving me papers or something?' But he says, 'You don’t know me, but my mom worked in a hospital you were in. She died a few months ago from cancer, but the last two years she was alive, all she could talk about was you and how horrible your circumstances were.'

We celebrate Thanksgiving once a year to say thank you, and it has its history in our nation's history, declared by the government that there would be that Thursday in November when we stop and give thanks. We remember, if we do historically, things that happened in our nation during the days of the Pilgrims.

The Passover celebration was commanded by God for His people to celebrate every year so they would know their history, where they came from, how they were slaves in Egypt, and through the sacrifice of that lamb and the blood applied to their homes, He provided salvation and brought them to the Promised Land. They were to teach that to their children through the Passover.

Someone once said it's like a boat and water. It's right for the church to be in the world—we're still here till Jesus takes us out—but it's wrong for the world to be in the church. A boat in water is good, that's what boats are for, but water inside a boat can sink it.

I think a good illustration of this progression is seen in the life of Lot in the Book of Genesis. Remember Abraham's nephew, who he took with him even though he wasn’t supposed to, and God blessed them both with huge herds. Jacob and his mom come up with a scheme to trick Isaac. Jacob straight-up lies to his dad and steals the blessing.

You've heard that phrase TGIF your whole life, Thank God It's Friday, I finally could have my life back. There was a bumper sticker years ago that said, 'I owe, I owe, so off to work I go,' from the Disney Snow White, you know, hi-ho, hi-ho. In other words, I know the Lord, I know I am here, I know my mission, I'm going to work because that's where God has given me an opportunity.

I sat with Bill in his car in the Placentia PD parking lot for about an hour and a half, almost two hours, and I had the privilege of sharing the gospel with him. I told him how God loved him enough to send His Son and put Him on a cross to punish our sins 2000 years ago. We celebrate the resurrection, and that’s what makes it a Good Friday—Jesus took our place, and though it’s sad, it’s the most wonderful Friday because our sins were paid for.

It was that day that Bill gave his life to Christ. I thought to myself, that’s why I’m out here, stuck in graveyards. I thought it was because somebody wasn’t doing their job right, but really, shortly after that, I got reassigned back to my detective job—it’s like the Lord was orchestrating things.
It kind of reminds me of Peter. Peter will take on the soldiers, fight them, but before a little campfire girl, he's gonna deny Jesus.
He runs all the way down south, outside of her jurisdiction, and he sits down under a juniper bush or tree and says, 'Take me home, country roads, I'm ready to go home. This is enough.'
God says, 'What are you doing here, Elijah?' It's the strangest question because God told him to go. I would've said, 'You told me,' but he doesn't say that.
God finally says to him, 'I have seven thousand in Israel who've never bowed the knee. You are not alone, Elijah.'
God is blessing that ministry so much. My son is in there all the time, and he loves it. He's an adventure kid!

When I take the mail out of my mailbox, which I do regularly, before I ever read any of it, I make sure of each piece—who it’s from and who it’s to. It makes a big difference. A father carries with it in the Bible the idea of affection. The son comes to the father and says, 'I'm hungry.' The father’s not gonna give him a stone; he’ll give him bread. If he asks for a fish, he doesn’t get a poisonous snake.
Even if we’re orphans, He’ll father us. This Father we can know is the Father of our souls.

Jacob served seven years for Rachel, and they seemed but a few days because of his love for her. But in the morning, after the wedding feast, behold, it was Leah! He said to Laban, 'What is this you’ve done to me? Was it not for Rachel that I served you? Why have you deceived me?'

In the Hebrew, it literally reads ‘he lifted up his feet.’ The idea is, before this, Jacob is alone, running from home, it’s dark, and it’s a hard road. But something happened in this dream that’s changing the way he’s on this journey—you might say he had happy feet now.

I was reminded of that time when Jacob, journeying to the house of Laban, came to a place where there was a well with a great stone upon it. Spurgeon says, even so, the tomb of Jesus is like a great well springing up with the purest water. Just as the stone was rolled away from the well, the stone was rolled away from His tomb, giving access to salvation.

As I'm looking at Greg hugging my son, I saw their angels. I must tell you what I saw—I saw their angels look at each other and smile approvingly, like, 'Yes, this is what we want. We want your people to know and love each other.'

Christmas time reminds me of sleep deprivation because my daughter was born on December 23rd, right before Christmas. I had just got hired at a church, leading worship for my first Christmas Eve. We went to the hospital on the 22nd, had her on the 23rd, brought her home on the 24th, and then I left to go to work—which, by the way, if you're a new parent, don't leave your wife the day you bring your baby home!

I think of the joy that my daughter has brought to me over the last 12 years. I can't imagine, though, having her and then knowing just 33 short years later that she would need to be sacrificed for the sins of humanity. Yet God gave His Son, for God so loved the world that He gave His only Son.

It's a beautiful thing that a baby's cry was what broke the silence between God and us. Before Jesus was born, there were 400 years of silence. So that baby's cry broke 400 years of silence, and He was dwelling with us.

Remember when Jesus raised the widow of Nain's son? Jesus came into that funeral, saw a woman weeping over her only son who had died, went over to the coffin, raised the young man from the dead, and then delivered him back to his mother.

I was talking to my grandson yesterday, and he was saying how he wants to go to heaven. He got excited, asking, 'What’s heaven going to be like? Will we be able to eat?' For the Prodigal Son, the father says nothing to him. He does not rub his nose in his sin. God’s not gonna do that to any of you either.

My grandkids always want me to tell the story where I did something stupid, like jamming it into the pool. They never ask about the fun times or the playhouse I built, just that dramatic, bloody part. I think they like knowing their Pastor Papa messed up sometimes.

I'm a bricklayer by trade. On the day of the accident, I was working alone on the roof of a new six-story building. Rather than carry 240 pounds of leftover bricks down by hand, I decided to lower them in a barrel using a pulley, but due to my surprise at being jerked off the ground suddenly—I weigh only 135 pounds—I lost my presence of mind.

I forgot to let go of the rope, and needless to say, I shot up the side of the building. Around the third floor, I met the barrel coming down at an impressive speed, which explains the fractured skull, abrasions, and broken collarbone. I kept going down, fingers jammed in the pulley, until I hit the bricks below, cracking vertebrae, and then, in pain, I lost my composure and let go of the rope again.

I came to their apartment, third story of this tenement housing, and sat down with Andre, the father. He didn’t speak English, I don’t speak much Spanish, and he looks at me seriously and says, 'Mi casa es su casa,' which I know means 'my house is your house,' but then he adds with a laugh, 'mi esposa is not your wife!' We all laughed, and I realized Andre had a good sense of humor, and it started out well.

I laid out the gospel for Andre through translation, and at the end, he said, 'I want to give my life to Christ too.'
